title: Thyssenkrupp: new boss, new job cuts?
text:
New CEO, not so new problems for Thyssenkrupp.

The German conglomerate has been struggling to turn itself around ...

And now might be looking at major job losses.

That's according to a memo seen by Reuters ...

In which Martina Merz says rebooting the ailing company will - quote - "not be possible without significant job cuts".

No figure has been mentioned - Thyssen has previously said it would cut 6,000 of a 162,000-strong workforce ...

Though sources close to the matter see that as not enough.

Merz took over from Guido Kerkhoff at the start of October.

Despite his efforts to simplify an overly complex structure, Thyssen was downgraded by two ratings agencies in August ...

Its shares by then losing around 40 per cent of their value since the start of the year - they have since recovered some ground.

Merz has remained tight-lipped over the ongoing auction process for the group's prized elevator division.

Though sources told Reuters the company's planning to give bidders access to the unit's data room in coming days.
